text: saw someone try to be language police in a recent thread where he asked someone else to post in a language that "everyone can understand". Unintended or intended. Not sure if it's healthy to put pressure on people to talk or share a certain way. You can always request for a translation if you feel left out and 95% of the time the person commenting can translate. We are not part of the same company or culture so imposing a language is not healthy to encourage vulnerable and frank and informal discussions?

text:
Hi all! Would be great if I could have your experienced advice:

I have been working in Sales for the past 8 years, and want to transition to PMM (or Strategy) Role. The reason: Past 3 companies I have worked with were start-up's, and the close collaboration b/w Sales & Marketing made me realise my knack for overall GTM planning (I don't like sales anymore...help me please!!). The problem: I have zero clue on where to and how to begin with this. I have 3 questions:
1. Where do I begin? (Currently on LinkedIn Learning courses on PMM, but if there's something else, I'd be thankful for your suggestions)
2. Since I am working in Sales, I am earning approx. 30LPA (60-40 split). If I get an opp in PMM in the future, what's the pay that I can expect (high/low/none/wishful thinking)?
3. In the current space, any suggestions on the orgs I should keep an eye out for, for any opps? (out of curiosity)
Thanks in advance

PS: I am comfortable with responses in any language... desperate for guidance, and I will use Google Translate if needed :D

elements.text:

text: Feedback should never be harsh. So minus points for your manager. Maybe you can communicate how you'd like your feedback.  Also, focus on learning and staying curious. Ask questions without hesitation and own up for not knowing shit. Figure out solutions, instead of just stating problems. And probably find a colleague who can proofread your work before sending it to your manager. You are new, it's uncomfortable, you WILL make mistakes, so focus on learning and growing. Hope this helps :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Feedback should never be harsh. So minus points for your manager. Maybe you can communicate how you'd like your feedback.  Also, focus on learning and staying curious. Ask questions without hesitation and own up for not knowing shit. Figure out solutions, instead of just stating problems. And probably find a colleague who can proofread your work before sending it to your manager. You are new, it's uncomfortable, you WILL make mistakes, so focus on learning and growing. Hope this helps

text:
Focus on experience. Learn as much as you can. People don't leave companies, they leave managers. In your case, your manager is the problem. Harsh feedback is a big no-no. I never scold or give harsh feedback to my team members (including VA).

On your part, you could make a list of crimes to not commit again - make a Google Keep (Notes).

If you're a VA or an intern or there are many people at your post in your company, asking the manager to be polite will backfire, you may get fired sooner.

I suggest to focus on the learning. Every day, spend 15 minutes on finding new jobs, and connecting with relevant people on LinkedIn. Just see what they do, how they do, why they do. They probably won't reply to DMs, so engage in conversations via comments on their posts. 

Open up and explore!

elements.text:

Open up and explore!

text:
Hey buddy, do everything that <@U030KV8R8RL> suggested. Nicely sums up all you can do on your side.

Also, be aware that your manager is harsh not because of your mistakes. It's because of certain incapability that s/he carries (Emotional Quotient). And always, this behavior just reflects poorly on them. 

Stay in this awareness and don't let the fear affect you and or quality of life. 

Keep looking for other opportunities.
